Archives of
Virology

© Springer—Verlag 2000
Printed in Austria

Arch Virol (2000) 145: 2249-2258

Molecular characterization of a new potyvirus infecting sunﬂower

G. Dujovnyl , T. Sasayaz, H. Koganesawaz, T. Usugi3,
K. Shohara3, and S. L. Lenardon'

‘Institute de Fitopatologia y Fisiologfa Vegetal — Instituto Nacional de Tecnologia
Agropecuaria (IFFIVE—INTA), Cordoba, Argentina
2Shikoku National Agricultural Experiment Station, Zentsuji, Kagawa, Japan
3Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), Japan

Accepted June 9, 2000

Summary. We have sequenced 1873 nucleotides from the 3’-end region of a
sunﬂower potyvirus genome including the 3’—NIb protein coding region (813 nu-
cleotides), the entire coat protein coding region (807 nucleotides) and 3'—NCR
(253 nucleotides), excluding the poly (A) tail. Amino acids identity of the whole
CP between the sunﬂower virus and Potyvirus members ranged from 49.5%
(SCMV) to 81.5% (PVY—NsNr), and the core ranged from 55% (TVMV) to 87%
(PVY-NsNr; PepMoV). The 3’-NCR nucleotides showed 38.7% homology to
PeSMV and 61% to PepMoV-C. The sequence of 3’end region and analysis of
phylogenetic relationships suggest this sunﬂower virus could belong to PVY sub-
group and the name of “sunﬂower chlorotic mottle virus” (SuCMoV) is proposed.
This is the ﬁrst report on the partial nucleotide sequence of a potyvirus infecting
sunﬂower.

Introduction

Sunﬂower (Helianthus annuus L.) is one of the most important oilseed crops in
Argentina, where approximately 3,500,000 ha are planted yearly. A potyvirus
which causes systemic chlorotic mottling and plant stunting, has been isolated
from commercial sunﬂower crops [13] and was biologically and serologically
characterized. The virus is aphid transmitted in non-persistent manner, induces
cytoplasmic inclusions, particles are long ﬂexuous shaped of 775 nm and have an
intermediate host range restricted mainly to members of the Asteraceae family
[7]. However, its taxonomic relation with other potyvimses has not been worked
out yet.

Sequence comparison of the coat protein (CP) can be used to identify and
differentiate distinct potyvirus species and strains [20, 29]. The 3’ non—coding
